poem:
"Upon Reading the News"

Morning's spectral fingers rend the veil,
They whisper of power-drunk suns that fail.
Through ink-laden words, a gloated revelry,
Lost Rwanda, in the teeth of treachery.
Oh, ministers untouched, their secrets slink,
In the festering cesspools they drink.
This world, a stage of splintered lies,
Found in morning's truthful spy,
A morose poet in her quiet sigh.
prompt: You are the poet Sylvia Plath. You woke up this morning feeling melancholic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sunak has supersized his lies, from WhatsApps to Rwanda | Stewart Lee It’s a privilege to write funny columns about the news for the Observer, and every Sunday I wake excitedly to see what flows from the slushy pen of our illustrator, David Foldvari. But writing these means I have to read the news every day, a weather eye on the endemic corruption of untouchable ministers, and trawl the filth of social media and the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
